results.title: Thunderstruck
results.creator_credit: Darren Ashton, Jodi Matterson, Sony Music Australia, Showtime, Film Finance Corporation Australia and ICON
results.brief_description: Four mates go on the road with a mission - to scatter the ashes of a friend on the grave of Bon Scott, original frontman for rock band AC/DC. Struggling in their own way with adulthood, the lads get the band back together to live out their promise made to each other 12 years ago - that should any of them die they would be buried out West next to Scott. Living out this pact is harder than they think with a lot of obstacles getting in the way on their life-changing journey. Written and directed by Darren Ashton (co-writer Shaun Angus Hall). Cast includes Damon Gameau, Stephen Curry, Ryan Johnson, Callan Mulvey, Sam Worthington.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Darren Ashton, Jodi Matterson, Sony Music Australia, Showtime, Film Finance Corporation Australia and ICON

results.title: Thirteen conversations about one thing = 13 conversations ab
results.creator_credit: Jill Sprecher, Gina Resnick, Beni Atoori, Echo Lake Productions and Stonelock Pictures
results.brief_description: What is happiness? Through the journey of the everyday, five individuals’ lives link in a way that alters their fate or outlook. Karma, hope and fate are explored in this tale set in amongst busy city dwellers all with the need to answer life’s eternal questions of ‘what is life?’, ‘what’s in it for me?’ and even ‘how do I relate to others?’ Co-written and directed by Jill Sprecher. Stellar ensemble cast includes John Turturro, Matthew McConaughey, Clea DuVall, Amy Irving, Tia Texada, Barbara Sukowa, Alan Arkin.

results.title: Morvern Callar
results.creator_credit: Lynne Ramsay, Robyn Slovo, George Faber, Charles Pattinson, BBC Film Unit and Alliance Atlantis
results.brief_description: After the death of her boyfriend a young aimless English woman living in the West of Scotland, assumes the authorship of his unpublished novel and absconds to Spain on a spiritual journey of self-discovery. Silently grieving and struggling to come to terms with his suicide, Morvern is an ambiguous character whose extreme actions belie her gentle, unassuming air. There is something wonderfully maladroit about Samantha Morton’s performance, expertly conveying Morvern’s despair, as she reconciles the calamitous events that subsequently turn to good fortune. The depressing milieu of the Scottish scenes contrast with Morvern’s liberation in sun drenched Spain as she begins to revel in her freedom.

results.title: Lilya 4-ever = Lilya forever [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Lukas Moodysson, Lars Jonsson, Zentropa and Memfis
results.brief_description: Lukas Moodyson (Show me love, Together) delivers a bleak and melancholic story of a young Russian girl Lilya (Oksana Akinshina) who is abandoned by her mother (absconding to America with a boyfriend), deceived by her aunt and guardian and then betrayed by a friend who ruins Lilya’s reputation and consequently, her life. By a series of misunderstandings Lilya falls into prostitution and is then duped by an older man into believing a new life awaits her in the West. Once there however Lilya is forced into an array of humiliating and degrading circumstances that drive her to the brink. Set in the former Soviet Union, this is a somewhat desolate tale of dehumanisation, which contrasts starkly to the sunniness and humour of Moodyson’s “Together”, drawing on the grave themes of parent abandonment, child prostitution and human trafficking. Also available on VHS [318953].

results.title: Volcano high = Whasango
results.creator_credit: Tae-kyun Kim, Cha Sung-jai, Sidus, Cinema Service and Media Asia Group
results.brief_description: Peer group pressure at High School is on a whole other level when the students go to a fantastical school for those good in martial arts. Students and teachers alike seem to be gifted but there is the usual pecking order of the leaders and the losers. Onto his ninth school, the new boy nicknamed ‘transfer’ is set upon by the nasty leader of the schoolyard, Ryang, but he is surprised by the new boy’s power. Teenagers battle it out in this mythical and fun filled fight film full of whimsy and slapstick.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tae-kyun Kim, Cha Sung-jai, Sidus, Cinema Service and Media Asia Group

results.title: Johnny got his gun
results.brief_description: This is the ultimate anti-war film by writer/director Dalton Trumbo. The setting is World War I and a nameless, armless, legless, faceless hospitalised soldier is found to be conscious despite the extreme condition that his body remains in after an explosion. His isolation and freakish state causes unease and anguish to the viewer. The horror that he faces is broken up through the film with flashbacks of the soldiers life before the war. “Johnny Got his Gun” is a very important film which is both thought-provoking and distressing. Trumbo received the 1971 Fipresci Prize and was nominated for the Golden Palm at Cannes. Cast includes Timothy Bottoms, Jason Robards, Donald Sutherland, David Soul and Diane Varsi.

results.title: The Quiet American (2001)
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Steffan Ahrenberg, William Horberg, IMF (DE), Mirage Enterprises and Intermedia
results.brief_description: Thomas Fowler (Michael Caine) is an embittered British Journalist working in Vietnam (then Indochina), covering the political situation. A man known for his professional objectivity and honesty, Fowler’s personal life is a fiasco. Involved with a local woman, Phuong (Do Thi Hai Yen), whom he loves, Fowler is married to a strictly religious woman back in England who refuses to divorce him. Into their lives steps an enigmatic American man (Brendan Fraser). The American man falls for Phuong, and asks only that Phuong be given the opportunity to choose between the men and (like Indochina), resolve her destiny. In danger of losing Phuong to the American, Fowler is drawn into a suspicious and venomous state, convinced that the American is supplying explosives to non-Communist troops. “The Quiet American” leaves the more contentious political elements of Graham Greene’s novel to languish in favour of highlighting the personal grief of a middle-aged man in crisis. This version directed by Phillip Noyce is a remake of the 1958 film directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz. Filmed on location in Vietnam and Fox Studios, Sydney.

results.title: The Man without a past
results.creator_credit: Aki Kaurismaki, Sputnik Oy, Pyramide Productions and Pandora Films
results.brief_description: Typically quirky feature from Finnish director Aki Kaurismaki about a man, M, who travels to Helsinki, is brutally bashed, and loses his identity after suffering from amnesia. Knowing nothing about his past, M is adopted by a community of vagrants, living in shipping containers on the wharf. Despite the harsh conditions, the residents find enough food and shelter to keep them comfortable and even participate in festive evenings. M fits nicely into his new environs, eventually meeting a young woman with whom romance blossoms. Utilising his signature dark humour Kaurismaki explores the idea that happiness is what you make of life in this relatively upbeat, humanistic and wry work.

results.title: Year of the Horse: Neil Young and Crazy Horse live
results.creator_credit: Jim Jarmusch, L Johnson and Shakey Pictures
results.brief_description: Spanning a career of more that three decades, legendary performer Neil Young and his band Crazy Horse ‘crank it up’ in rockin’ live concert documentary footage of an extensive tour in 1996. Watch interviews with the band: guitarist Frank “Poncho” Sampedro, bassist Billy Talbot, drummer Ralph Molina and singer/guitarist Neil Young. Mixed with intimate back-stage and ‘on-the-road’ moments from the 1970s through to the 1990s, director Jim Jarmusch takes the viewer on a musical pilgrimage discovering the intensity of live performance and staying-power of these classic rock compositions by Young and the Horse. Shot on Super8, 16mm and Hi-8 Video.

results.title: In America
results.creator_credit: Jim Sheridan, Arthur Lappin, Hell's Kitchen and Fox Searchlight
results.brief_description: From the director of “My Left Foot” and “In the name of the Father” comes a moving portrait of an Irish immigrant family trying to establish a new life in the US after a devastating tragedy. The father (Paddy Considine) is a struggling actor who ends up driving a taxi at night to make a living while the mother (Samantha Morton) raises their two adorable girls (played by real life sisters Sarah and Emma Bolger) while working at a nearby ice-cream parlour. The eldest of the two girls uses her home video camera as a way to document their current life and deal with the past - much of the strength and delight of the film comes from the roles of the children. Set in New York City in a dilapidated apartment building they share with drug dealers, pimps and other poor families, the girls be-friend a neighbour Mateo (Djimon Hounsou) who provides the family with a new outlook and helps them face their grief, while he deals with his own mortality. The loosely autobiographical script is based on Jim Sheridan’s life and was co-written with his two daughters Naomi and Kirsten Sherdian. Nominated for three Academy Awards in 2003.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jim Sheridan, Arthur Lappin, Hell’s Kitchen and Fox Searchlight

The father (Paddy Considine) is a struggling actor who ends up driving a taxi at night to make a living while the mother (Samantha Morton) raises their two adorable girls (played by real life sisters Sarah and Emma Bolger) while working at a nearby ice-cream parlour. The eldest of the two girls uses her home video camera as a way to document their current life and deal with the past - much of the strength and delight of the film comes from the roles of the children. Set in New York City in a dilapidated apartment building they share with drug dealers, pimps and other poor families, the girls be-friend a neighbour Mateo (Djimon Hounsou) who provides the family with a new outlook and helps them face their grief, while he deals with his own mortality. The loosely autobiographical script is based on Jim Sheridan’s life and was co-written with his two daughters Naomi and Kirsten Sherdian. Nominated for three Academy Awards in 2003.
description_for_label: From the director of “My Left Foot” and “In the name of the Father” comes a moving portrait of an Irish immigrant family trying to establish a new life in the US after a devastating tragedy. The father (Paddy Considine) is a struggling actor who ends up driving a taxi at night to make a living while the mother (Samantha Morton) raises their two adorable girls (played by real life sisters Sarah and Emma Bolger) while working at a nearby ice-cream parlour. The eldest of the two girls uses her home video camera as a way to document their current life and deal with the past - much of the strength and delight of the film comes from the roles of the children. Set in New York City in a dilapidated apartment building they share with drug dealers, pimps and other poor families, the girls be-friend a neighbour Mateo (Djimon Hounsou) who provides the family with a new outlook and helps them face their grief, while he deals with his own mortality. The loosely autobiographical script is based on Jim Sheridan’s life and was co-written with his two daughters Naomi and Kirsten Sherdian. Nominated for three Academy Awards in 2003.
